key_points: The U.S. House of Representatives has voted to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
35 Republicans voted in favor of the commission, despite leadership's efforts to block the bill.
The bill, now headed to the Senate, mirrors the structure of the 9/11 Commission.
House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell both opposed the commission.
House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer mentioned that McCarthy received his requested compromises on the commission's structure.
Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell dismissed the need for the commission, endorsing existing Congressional investigations instead.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested the possibility of conducting regular committee hearings if the Senate blocks the commission.
The proposed commission aims to produce a report with recommendations to prevent future attacks and to examine security failures.
Some Republicans, including Senator Susan Collins, have expressed support for the commission, potentially with modifications.
Former President Donald Trump urged Republicans to oppose the commission, labeling it a 'trap' set by 'the radical left.'
spokespersons: Bennie Thompson (House Homeland Security Committee Chairman, Democrat)
Zoe Lofgren (Democratic Representative, House Administration Committee Chair)
